text: the anime essential series has afforded
me the opportunity to talk about vintage
anime in a way that I simply couldn't
before and not only has that been a lot
of fun but especially in the case of my
recent on Ohana video I think it's
allowed me to produce some of my best
work but there is a problem with the
series as a concept that's baked right
there into the title the anime I talked
about have to be essential which just
doesn't leave much room to explore the
older shows that are creative
interesting and well-made but definitely
aren't must-watch masterpieces or
influential cultural touchstones the
guilty pleasures popcorn fodder and
filler shows of seasons past that were
good and deserved to be talked about but
don't really belong on anyone's bucket
list so to give myself space to talk
about these anime non-essentials I'm
creating a new sub series and the first
subject I'll be tackling with it is
outbreak company a satirical ISA Kai
anime that came out just as the ISA Kai
boom was first hit in full swing back in
2013 before we get into that this video
is sponsored by book Walker kadokawa's
official ebook store where you can read
hundreds of English translated light
novels and manga including outbreak
company right on your phone tablet or PC
in fact from now until September 30th
they're giving away the first volume of
outbreak company and a few other series
for free stick around to the end to
learn more the original outbreak company
light novels first entered publication
in 2011 and funny enough their anime
adaptation first aired in October of
2013 the same month that kono Suba first
light novel vol first hit store shelves
I do think that fans of Kazuma and COEs
adventures will find a lot to love in
this show maybe even enough to sate them
until crunchyroll releases the new movie
but you shouldn't go into outbreak
company expecting an e sekai parody per
say its interest lies less in skewering
the overused tropes of the genre and
more in using the trapped in another
world premise as a lens through which to
examine the real target of its satire
otaku culture outbreak company shares
its base premise with the aggressively
mediocre gate one day a Fantasyland
appears in the heart of Japan in this
case deep in the suicide forest of
al-qaeda Hara and as the government
struggles to deal with this new scenario
they enlist the help of an otaku guide
of Sauron
that's about where the similarities end
though since this isn't a work of
masturbatory military propaganda the
fantasy empire on the other side doesn't
blindly jump into a war they can't win
with a world they have zero intel on
instead the Japanese government sends a
party of emissaries to explore the
portal they're swiftly brought before
the Empress of the new world and before
long the suddenly neighboring nations
enter tenuous diplomatic talks each with
their own agendas of course this
pre-industrial land is a treasure trove
of untapped natural resources even
before you consider the staggering
potential of its magical properties and
Japan wants to capitalize on all of that
but they need to offer an export of
equal value in exchange and noticing
that this world doesn't have an
entertainment industry the visiting
bureaucrats hatch a brilliant scheme
foreign nations in our world already go
nuts for anime manga and other pieces of
otaku culture so it stands to reason
that a populace starved for
entertainment would only love it more
needing an expert to curate their new
export business the government puts out
a hiring call for otaku and SHINee
chicano a hikikomori high school dropout
aces his interview and lands a job as
the new CEO of MU tech before he knows
it literally because they drugged and
kidnap him right there in the interview
room
Shinichi finds himself living and
working in this strange new world under
the watchful eyes of a shady government
bureaucrat named matsuba and an expert
JSDF soldier and closeted fujiyoshi
named Minori
who serves as his bodyguard he's not
trapped in this new world per se but
since its existence and the location of
the portal are both national secrets and
he only knows the first one he may as
well be though his otaku knowledge is
impressive it's SHINee cheese inherent
disposability as a jobless teenage
shut-in that made him the ideal man for
this particular job still it's not all
bad he gets to live in a massive mansion
with an equally massive anime and manga
collection furnished by the Japanese
government and he enjoys being waited on
by his beautiful half-elf maid Musil and
his lizard manservant Brooks who is
equally beautiful in his own way they
both become SHINee cheese first converts
to otaku ISM initially much of his time
is spent explaining the nuances of anime
and manga over
daily tea with the almighty empress of
the holy Eldon's empire Petrarca who
looks like a little girl because of
course she does although thankfully she
is actually sixteen just three years
younger than our hero so as far as anime
goes it could be a lot worse to be fair
it could also be better Shinichi does
get very excited about her looks before
he knows her age and if that's setting
off alarm bells in your head this might
not be the anime for you
outbreak company has more than its share
of hit or miss pervy otaku humor much of
it concentrated in the first few
episodes and it doesn't handle that
nearly as well as the likes of save
highschool DxD at his worst chinny cheek
can be a creep on par with Mineta from
my hero academia OGG ling and making
lewd comments about every girl he meets
often before even learning their names
and while that kind of thing ranges from
amusing to tolerable when it's coming in
small doses from a supporting character
it's a lot harder to stomach in a
protagonist especially when some of
those girls don't really reciprocate and
he never takes the hint thankfully this
is not his defining character trait and
he does mellow out as the story goes on
but it bugged me and I can see it
putting some people off the show
entirely or it might not bother you at
all the first time I watched this when I
was 20 I remember laughing at a lot of
the jokes that made my eyes roll today
either way Shinichi does have plenty of
good points to offset the bad he's
intelligent observant kind-hearted and
surprisingly considerate in other
contexts and personally I find it hard
to completely dislike any character or
show for that matter that starts
dropping Kaiji references in episode 2 I
know that sounds a bit shallow but
outbreak company is one of the most
passionate and inclusive love letters to
otaku media out there if you enjoy anime
and manga no matter what your tastes are
it's all but guaranteed that you'll spot
a copyright safe parody of at least one
of your favorites in the background of
just the first three episodes and
depending on how hard core of an otaku
you are I'd almost recommend it based on
that alone there's not many shows out
there where you'll find nods to hotter
Akuma sama scrapped princess Inazuma
Eleven Prince of tennis attack on Titan
Doraemon tokimeki memorial Gundam Rental
magicka manam
kay Haku Oki milky holmes Haruhi on
Ohana multiple Miyazaki movies and my
boy Kai G+ dozens more anime and manga
and even a few live-action movies like
The Matrix and Shaolin Soccer in the
space of just 12 episodes and it goes
well beyond making simple references
episodes 6 through 10 of the series
offers sharp satirical takes on various
aspects of otaku dumb ranging from
hilarious parodies of sports anime and
obligatory swimsuit episodes to
explorations of more esoteric topics
like the culture of Akihabara tokusatsu
film production and the hikikomori
lifestyle the more anime you've seen and
the more you know about otaku in general
the funnier this show will be for you
though of course conversely that does
mean that a lot of the jokes will be
lost on more casual viewers the
references are so dense that even I
missed quite a few of them so you're
either gonna scratch your head wondering
why every time someone gets knocked out
they just happen to land like this or
you're already giggling about it that's
just the kind of show this is but as
inside jokey as outbreak company is what
I really love about it is that it's not
exclusionary Shinichi
isn't interested in gate keeping his
fandom he wants to share the shows books
movies and games he loves with as many
people as possible and the only kind of
fans that the show paints in an
unambiguously negative light are the
ones who put others down or get into
heated arguments over petty differences
in taste it draws direct parallels
between that kind of fan bickering and
the vitriolic interracial mudslinging
inherent to its tolkien-esque setting
and when Shinichi eventually found his
otaku school where children of the Elden
Empire noble and commoner human dwarf
and elf alike can come together to learn
both Japanese and key cultural concepts
like absolute territory and the
difference between semis and K's he
strives to use the education he's
providing to break down those barriers
the power that education has to enrich
our lives and make us better people is
something that outbreak company really
loves to hammer home
moreover the show asserts that manga
anime games and other pop narrative
media are very much literature
themselves that with
the right mindset they can be just as
useful textbooks as the ones that you
sold your kidneys to buy and then used
for a single semester and as a guy whose
main job is writing literary analysis of
anime that is a message I can really get
behind and it's far from the only one
here outbreak company was written by
Ichiro ceccacci the creator of scrapped
princess and coffin princess Chaka a
pair of more serious dramatic fantasy
stories with some genuinely interesting
philosophical underpinnings so while it
is a lot goofier in tone than either of
those this anime is deft at exploring
thought-provoking topics when it wants
to be and the characters who drive its
comedy have a surprising amount of depth
to them the anime sadly doesn't have
much time to dive into that outside of
the core cast but there's more to almost
everyone here than you'd first think and
in particular I really enjoyed patacas
character arc while she's initially more
than a little insufferable she grows a
great deal after finding essentially her
first ever friends in SHINee Chi and
Musa letting go of deep-rooted prejudice
learning to be a more level-headed
leader and becoming a lot less entitled
as the series goes on though she still
has an ego as is demonstrated
hilariously in the conclusion of the
tokusatsu episode my favorite part of
her arc has to be episode 8 overwhelmed
by her responsibilities as Empress and
the trauma of how she got that job at
just 16 years old
petrarca retreats into her room
resolving to live as a hikikomori
playing games watching anime and reading
books all day long Shinichi
a former hikikomori himself uses his
expertise in the subject to help her
indulge herself and eventually get it
out of her system the episode highlights
how guilt over being a burden to their
loved ones coupled with social anxiety
can trap people in this shut-in
lifestyle and make it harder and harder
to leave their rooms the longer they
retreat from their responsibilities but
ultimately it posits that such fears are
mostly misplaced it turns out that
patacas attendants and family are really
just worried about her and they respond
to her emergence not with scorn but with
relief and love that's probably a
message a lot of people in that
situation need to
here and that episode represents one of
the most thoughtful nuanced explorations
of the hiki Komori phenomenon that I've
seen this side of welcome to the NHK in
general outbreak company isn't afraid to
address the more toxic aspects of otaku
'dom and I really appreciated how mature
it was in handling them I wish I could
say the show was so competent in dealing
with every sensitive topic it chooses to
tackle but it does have some major blind
spots particularly in how it addresses
racism it's not all bad mind you it
presents the doublethink of bigotry in
an impressively realistic manner and I
think the way the otaku students learn
to slowly move past their prejudices
really works but there's this scene
where our hero sees the absolute
dictator of a racially stratified Empire
screaming and hurling slurs at a
terrified half ethnic maid and his first
thought is this is exactly like that
time a girl turned me down because I'm a
nerd which is a whole can of worms unto
itself but let's stay focused the intent
of this I believe is to help the show's
otaku audience empathize with musel's
plight and to demonstrate how awful
prejudice is which is a good message but
sending it in this way creates a false
equivalence that utterly trivializes the
horrors of real racial injustice Musil
had to earn her citizenship by being a
child soldier in the army of the woman
who's currently screaming at her chin
Ichi can take his sexually entitled
first world problems and shove them I do
really want to focus on the positives of
the show in this video so I'd have let
that slide if Shinichi didn't
immediately follow it up by saying
[Music]
9zu dhoka dhoka dhoka soya Muruga book
that's not blinken oh do I even have to
explain what's wrong with that statement
if you want to be charitable you could
argue that maybe he's talking about the
ideals present in otaku media and not
how his country actually treats minority
groups and foreigners but without making
that distinction it really sounds like
he thinks Japan is free of racial
prejudice and inequality which makes him
and by proxy the show since his
statement goes entirely unchallenged see
to be totally infuriatingly clueless
about the whole topic and since the
first arc is largely about that topic
getting through it can be pretty rough
in places though to be clear I found
that it was worth powering through my
frustration and enjoying everything else
the show had to offer and it's not like
outbreak company isn't critical of other
aspects of Japanese society Matoba is as
close as the show has to a main villain
and he's basically the living embodiment
of shady politics and the right-wing
nationalism of Japan's ruling party the
LDP an ideology the show seems to take
particular issue with considering that
the villains of the first arc are ultra
nationalist terrorists the soccer
episode highlights how sports can be
used to fuel dangerous jingoism and the
last arc well I don't want to spoil too
much but it doesn't exactly paint the
Japanese government in a positive light
and it advocates strongly for cultural
cross pollination in otaku media
unfortunately the show doesn't give that
arc nearly enough time to explore all of
the interesting ideas that it brings up
I'm only just starting to read the light
novels so I can't be sure but the
jarring tonal shift going into those
last two episodes really makes it feel
like they rushed and rewrote some plot
points to give the show a more
conclusive conclusion fun as it is
outbreak company is one of those anime
that feels like it's being held back by
the constraints of its adaptation but it
is fun as critical as I've been of its
worst points I do still heartily
recommend it overall the first arc is a
bit slow and the last arc is a mess but
episodes 4 through 10 are gold and the
show works exceptionally well from
beginning to end if the main thing
you're coming to it for is light-hearted
geeky comedy with great music stellar
voice acting and especially incredible
animation on top of that seriously some
of these action scenes had me picking my
jaw up off the floor I think that most
anime fans will be more than satisfied
without brake company warts and all that
said I am getting the distinct
impression that the light novels might
offer an even richer and more satisfying
narrative experience which brings us
back to today's sponsor book Walker
because if you're interested in reading
Outbreak company there has never been a
better time until the end of the month
in partnership with their publisher J
novel club book Walker is giving away
the first volumes of in another world
with my smartphone der werewolf
sorceress stabber orphan I saved too
many girls and caused the apocalypse and
obviously outbreak company for free to
all users
so if you sign up now you will
immediately have five great new books to
read and if any of those entice you to
read further you're in luck because as
part of this promotion until September
30th subsequent volumes of all of those
series are on sale for 20% off which
means that if you use my promo code
basement to buy volume 2 of say outbreak
company the 600 yen discount you get
will bring the total price down to a
little under 60 cents which is an
absolute steal especially for a textbook
for the low low price of free there is
no reason not to at least sign up and
download these books and that promo code
basement once again will work for the
entire first month of your membership so
you have a good while to figure out
exactly which work of otaku literature
you most want to use it on on the next
basement book club we will be covering a
silent voice so if you're looking for
suggestions that's a good option - I'm
Jeff through professional [ __ ]
wishing you good reading from my
mother's basement
